question: [File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_fullnode_network_configs()] [Iterator safety] The fullnode_networks.iter() loop - can the underlying Vec be modified during iteration, causing iterator invalidation and skipped validation? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_fullnode_network_configs()] [Chain ID unused] The _chain_id parameter is never used - should different chains have different fullnode network requirements (e.g., mainnet requiring specific networks)? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_fullnode_network_configs()] [VFN vs PFN] Are ValidatorFullnode and PublicFullnode treated identically in empty network check? Should VFNs have stricter requirements than PFNs? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_fullnode_network_configs()] [Network config validation] Does the function validate the contents of each NetworkConfig beyond network_id, or can attackers set malicious network addresses/ports that pass validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [None bypass for validators] If validator_network is None for a validator (line 166), can the validator still participate in consensus using alternative network channels, breaking security assumptions? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Network ID validation] The check at line 176 for is_validator_network() - can an attacker create a custom network_id that passes this check but routes to a public/untrusted network? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Mutual auth bypass] If mutual_authentication is false (line 192), validators can communicate without mutual auth - can MITM attackers impersonate validators to inject malicious consensus messages? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Node type confusion] The check at line 184 prevents non-validators from having validator network config - but can attackers modify node_type after validation to escalate to validator? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Redundant checks] Lines 176-181 and 184-189 both check node type - is there a logical flaw where a validator with wrong network_id could pass one check but fail another inconsistently? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Partial config] If validator_network is Some() but contains invalid fields beyond network_id and mutual_authentication, does validation catch all malicious configurations? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Chain ID dependency] The _chain_id parameter is unused - should mainnet validators have stricter mutual authentication requirements than testnet? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Network address validation] Does the function validate the actual network addresses, ports, and connection settings in validator_network_config beyond the basic checks shown? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Function: sanitize_validator_network_config()] [Key validation] Does validator network config include validation of cryptographic keys, or can a validator be configured with invalid/weak keys that compromise consensus? (Critical)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Integration] [Sanitizer ordering] If ConsensusConfig depends on validated NetworkConfig, but ConsensusConfig is sanitized first (line 54) before network configs (lines 58, 67), can this ordering enable dependency attacks? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Integration] [State consistency] If multiple sanitizers modify or validate the same underlying data structures, can race conditions between sanitizers lead to inconsistent validation state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Integration] [Error propagation] Do sub-config sanitizers (AdminServiceConfig, ApiConfig, etc.) properly return errors, or can they silently fail allowing invalid configs to pass? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Integration] [Shared state mutation] Does any sanitizer mutate shared state that affects other sanitizers, creating implicit dependencies that attackers can exploit? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Integration] [Validator vs fullnode config overlap] Can a config be simultaneously valid for both validator and fullnode types, allowing privilege escalation after validation? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Memory safety] [Option unwrapping] The match on Option values (lines 84, 94, 174) - are all None cases handled safely, or can panics occur causing validator crashes? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Memory safety] [Vec iteration] The vector iteration in sanitize_fullnode_network_configs - are there any bounds checking issues that could cause out-of-bounds reads? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Memory safety] [Reference lifetime] Does the &NodeConfig reference remain valid throughout all sanitizer calls, or can it be invalidated causing use-after-free? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Concurrency] [Thread safety] If sanitize() is called concurrently from multiple threads with the same NodeConfig, can race conditions corrupt validation state? (High)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Concurrency] [Shared references] Are NodeConfig fields accessed through shared references (&) thread-safe, or can concurrent reads during sanitization see inconsistent data? (Medium)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Error handling] [Error types] Does Error::ConfigSanitizerFailed provide sufficient detail for security auditing, or can attackers hide malicious configs behind generic error messages? (Low)

[File: aptos-core/config/src/config/config_sanitizer.rs] [Error handling] [Error recovery] If sanitization fails, is there a recovery mechanism, or does the node fail to start completely? Can attackers DoS nodes by forcing validation failures? (Medium)
